dialogs.original: Come, Marcus; come, kinsmen; this is the way.    Sir boy, now let me see your archery;    Look ye draw home enough, and 'tis there straight.    Terras Astraea reliquit:    Be you remember'd, Marcus, she's gone, she's fled.    Sirs, take you to your tools. You, cousins, shall    Go sound the ocean, and cast your nets;    Happily you may catch her in the sea;    Yet there's as little justice as at land:    No; Publius and Sempronius, you must do it;    'Tis you must dig with mattock and with spade,    And pierce the inmost centre of the earth:    Then, when you come to Pluto's region,    I pray you, deliver him this petition;    Tell him, it is for justice and for aid,    And that it comes from old Andronicus,    Shaken with sorrows in ungrateful Rome.    Ah, Rome! Well, well; I made thee miserable    What time I threw the people's suffrages    On him that thus doth tyrannize o'er me.    Go, get you gone; and pray be careful all,    And leave you not a man-of-war unsearch'd:    This wicked emperor may have shipp'd her hence;    And, kinsmen, then we may go pipe for justice.
dialogs.translated: Come on, Marcus, come; kinsmen, this is the way.[To Young LUCIUS] Sir boy, now let me see your archery; make sure you draw home and shoot straight. Terras Astraea reliquit: remember it. Marcus, justice is gone, she ran away. Sirs, pick up your weapons. You, cousins, will go around the ocean and cast your nets; perhaps you can catch her in the sea. But theres just as little justice there as on landso never mind. No, Publius and Sempronius, you must do it; dig with a fork and spade until you get to the center of the Earth. Then, when you get to Plutos underworld, give him this petition. Tell him I ask for justice and for help, and that it comes from old Andronicus, who suffers in ungrateful Rome. Oh, Rome! Well, I made you miserable when I threw the peoples votes on the tyrant Saturninus. Go, go away; and be careful everyone, and don't let a ship get by without searching it. This wicked emperor may have had her shipped her away. And then, kinsmen, we're searching for justice in vain.

dialogs.original: O Publius, is not this a heavy case,To see thy noble uncle thus distract?
dialogs.translated: Oh, Publius, isnt this distressing, to see your noble uncle so mad?

dialogs.original: Therefore, my lord, it highly us concerns    By day and night to attend him carefully,    And feed his humour kindly as we may,    Till time beget some careful remedy.
dialogs.translated: And for that reason, my lord, we make sure to watch him all day and night, and take care of him as best we can, until perhaps time will heal him.

dialogs.original: Kinsmen, his sorrows are past remedy.    Join with the Goths; and with revengeful war    Take wreak on Rome for this ingratitude,    And vengeance on the traitor Saturnine.
dialogs.translated: Kinsmen, his sorrows are past fixing. Join the Goths, and by going to war take revenge on Rome for this ingratitude, and on the traitor Saturnine.

dialogs.original: Publius, how now! how now, my masters!What, have you met with her?
dialogs.translated: Publius, how are you? How are you, my masters? What, have you found her?

dialogs.original: No, my good lord; but Pluto sends you word,    If you will have Revenge from hell, you shall:    Marry, for Justice, she is so employ'd,    He thinks, with Jove in heaven, or somewhere else,    So that perforce you must needs stay a time.
dialogs.translated: No, my good lord; but Pluto says that you will have revenge from hell, if you ask for it. He thinks that Justice is busy with Jove in heaven, or somewhere else, so you need to wait a bit.

dialogs.original: He doth me wrong to feed me with delays.    I'll dive into the burning lake below,    And pull her out of Acheron by the heels.    Marcus, we are but shrubs, no cedars we    No big-boned men framed of the Cyclops' size;    But metal, Marcus, steel to the very back,    Yet wrung with wrongs more than our backs can bear:    And, sith there's no justice in earth nor hell,    We will solicit heaven and move the gods    To send down Justice for to wreak our wrongs.    Come, to this gear. You are a good archer, Marcus;
dialogs.translated: Its wrong to make me wait. Ill dive into the burning lake in the underworld, and pull her out of Acheron by the heels. Marcus, were just shrubs, not cedars, not big-boned men like the cyclops. Were just metal and steel, Marcus, and yet weve had more wrongs done to us than our backs can bear. And, since theres no justice in earth or hell, well pray to heaven and move the gods to send down Justice to right our wrongs. Come, lets do it. You are a good archer, Marcus.

dialogs.original: 'Ad Jovem,' that's for you: here, 'Ad Apollinem:'    'Ad Martem,' that's for myself:    Here, boy, to Pallas: here, to Mercury:    To Saturn, Caius, not to Saturnine;    You were as good to shoot against the wind.    To it, boy! Marcus, loose when I bid.    Of my word, I have written to effect;    There's not a god left unsolicited.
dialogs.translated: "To Jove," that's for you; here, "To Apollo"; "To Mars," that's for me. Here, boy, to Pallas; here, to Mercury; to Saturn; Caius. Not to Saturnineyou might as well shoot against the wind. Get to it, boy! Marcus, let your arrow fly when I tell you. I swear Ive written to every god for justice.

dialogs.original: Kinsmen, shoot all your shafts into the court:We will afflict the emperor in his pride.
dialogs.translated: Kinsmen, shoot all your arrows at the palace; well annoy the prideful emperor.

dialogs.original: Now, masters, draw.
dialogs.translated: Now, masters, draw.

dialogs.original: O, well said, Lucius!Good boy, in Virgo's lap; give it Pallas.
dialogs.translated: Oh, nicely done, Lucius! Good boy, in Virgo's lap; give it to Pallas.

dialogs.original: My lord, I aim a mile beyond the moon;Your letter is with Jupiter by this.
dialogs.translated: My lord, I aim a mile beyond the moon; I've sent your letter to Jupiter.

dialogs.original: Ha, ha!Publius, Publius, what hast thou done?See, see, thou hast shot off one of Taurus' horns.
dialogs.translated: Ha, ha! Publius, Publius, what have you done? See, see, you've shot off one of Taurus's horns.

dialogs.original: This was the sport, my lord: when Publius shot,    The Bull, being gall'd, gave Aries such a knock    That down fell both the Ram's horns in the court;    And who should find them but the empress' villain?    She laugh'd, and told the Moor he should not choose    But give them to his master for a present.
dialogs.translated: This was the game, my lord; when Publius shot his arrow, Taurus butted heads with Aries, and both the rams horns fell down into the court. And who should find them but the empress's villain? She laughed, and told the Moor he should give them to the emperor as a present.

dialogs.original: Why, there it goes: God give his lordship joy!
dialogs.translated: Why, there they go: God give joy to his lordship!

dialogs.original: News, news from heaven! Marcus, the post is come.Sirrah, what tidings? have you any letters?Shall I have justice? what says Jupiter?
dialogs.translated: News, news from heaven! Marcus, the post is come. Man, what do you hear? Do you have any letters for me? Will we have justice? What does Jupiter say?

dialogs.original: O, the gibbet-maker! he says that he hath takenthem down again, for the man must not be hanged tillthe next week.
dialogs.translated: Oh, the gibbet-maker! He says that he has taken the gibbets down again, for the man wont be hanged until next week.

dialogs.original: But what says Jupiter, I ask thee?
dialogs.translated: But what does Jupiter say, I ask you?

dialogs.original: Alas, sir, I know not Jupiter; I never drank with himin all my life.
dialogs.translated: Sorry, sir, I dont know Jupiter; Ive never had a drink with him in my life.

dialogs.original: Why, villain, art not thou the carrier?
dialogs.translated: But villain, aren't you the messenger?

dialogs.original: Ay, of my pigeons, sir; nothing else.
dialogs.translated: Yes, I carry pigeons, sirnothing else.

dialogs.original: Why, didst thou not come from heaven?
dialogs.translated: Why, didn't you come from heaven?

dialogs.original: From heaven! alas, sir, I never came there God    forbid I should be so bold to press to heaven in my    young days.   Why, I am going with my pigeons to the    tribunal plebs, to take up a matter of brawl    betwixt my uncle and one of the emperial's men.
dialogs.translated: From heaven! Oh, sir, Ive never been there. God forbid I should barge into heaven when Im still so young. Why, Im going with my pigeons to the tribune of the plebs, to deal with a fight between my uncle and one of the emperors soldiers.

dialogs.original: Why, sir, that is as fit as can be to serve for    your oration;   and let him deliver the pigeons to    the emperor from you.
dialogs.translated: [To TITUS] Why, sir, this is the perfect messenger for your speech. Let him take the pigeons to the emperor from you.

dialogs.original: Tell me, can you deliver an oration to the emperorwith a grace?
dialogs.translated: Tell me, can you deliver a speech to the emperor with a grace?

dialogs.original: Nay, truly, sir, I could never say grace in all my life.
dialogs.translated: No, truly, sir, I've never said grace in my life.

dialogs.original: Sirrah, come hither: make no more ado,    But give your pigeons to the emperor:    By me thou shalt have justice at his hands.    Hold, hold; meanwhile here's money for thy charges.    Give me pen and ink. Sirrah, can you with a grace    deliver a supplication?
dialogs.translated: Man, come here; dont say anything else, but just bring your pigeons to the emperor; youll get justice from him, for my sake. Wait, wait; heres money for your trouble. Give me pen and ink. Man, can you deliver a petition gracefully?

dialogs.original: Ay, sir.
dialogs.translated: Yes, sir.

dialogs.original: Then here is a supplication for you. And when you    come to him, at the first approach you must kneel,    then kiss his foot, then deliver up your pigeons,   and    then look for your reward. I'll be at hand, sir; see    you do it bravely.
dialogs.translated: Then here is a petition for you. And when you come to him, you must first kneel, then kiss his foot, then give him your pigeons, and then wait for your reward. I'll be close by, sir; make sure you do it well.

dialogs.original: I warrant you, sir, let me alone.
dialogs.translated: Leave it to me, sir.

dialogs.original: Sirrah, hast thou a knife? come, let me see it.    Here, Marcus, fold it in the oration;    For thou hast made it like an humble suppliant.    And when thou hast given it the emperor,    Knock at my door, and tell me what he says.
dialogs.translated: Do you have a knife? Come, give it to me. Here, Marcus, fold it in the letter, for youve made it look like a humble petition. And when hes given it to the emperor, knock at my door, and tell me what he says.

dialogs.original: God be with you, sir; I will.
dialogs.translated: God be with you, sir; I will.

dialogs.original: Come, Marcus, let us go. Publius, follow me.
dialogs.translated: Come, Marcus, let's go. Publius, follow me.
